4068.text:
but the information that then sits behind
that would be limited to what is necessary

4074.text:
The tax system, the health system, the passport
system and all of this does not have to be

4080.text: linked in one place in my view.

4083.text:
We have time for one last question and we
have lots of hands up but to you sir.

4097.text:
Shami, I wanted to ask you, as a political
junkie, when I get sick of watching Australian

4105.text:
politics, I've paid quite a bit of attention
to your country’s.

4109.text: You really are a junkie then aren’t you?

4115.text:
You spoke, just now about the importance of
parliamentary institutions but one trend I've

4122.text:
noticed inherent in the Westminster system
is that we often get governments or lower

4129.text:
houses of parliament that are not representative
of the diverse political views of the population

4137.text:
which is why I guess I'm in favour of proportional
representation.

4141.text:
My question is, do you agree and if so, how
do we a) convince the rest of the population

4148.text:
that such a thing is necessary and b) how
do we convince our major parties to vote for

4154.text:
a change that is fundamentally against their
own political self interest?

4161.text:
To go to the last bit of your question first,
I'm not sure it is wholly against all sorts

4166.text:
of party’s self interest and it's not surprising
that political parties sometimes change their

4171.text:
views about all sorts of things to do with
boundaries, voting systems etcetera, etcetera

4177.text:
according to how they think it will fit with
their immediate needs.

4183.text:
I'm not sure whether PR is the answer because
I think with or without a proportional representative

4192.text:
system, you end up with deals and negotiations
and coalitions.

4198.text:
They're either in a big party or they're across
a number of smaller parties and one way or

4203.text:
another people don’t always get what they
think they voted for.

4209.text:
So I'm not someone who has very strong opinions
about this issue.

4215.text:
I think at the moment in Britain with the
European question and frankly even the UK

4222.text:
question because there’s talk of another
Scottish Referendum, so I think we probably

4229.text:
realistically in Britain have bigger priorities
right now.

4233.text:
However, I think there are a lot of people
including in my party and in other parties

4239.text:
who are sympathetic to your point of view
and it may well come in Britain in the longer

4248.text:
term, whether it is necessarily always a better
system, I don’t know.

4253.text:
The really important thing I think for me
is that people get involved.

4258.text:
For all its problems and my party does have
significant problems at the moment, it is

4264.text:
currently at over half a million people, the
biggest or the most numerous political party

4269.text:
in Europe and some people find that scary
and other people like me find that exciting

4278.text:
and I think those people need to be involved
and to be active in policy making.

4284.text:
I think I want to see people from more diverse
backgrounds put themselves forward for election

4291.text:
That’s the kind of transformation that I'm
quite excited about.

4294.text:
The precise voting system, I’ll leave to
political junkies and experts like you.
